newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian cyclone hits rice, coconut crops.
newsitem.headline: Indian cyclone hits rice, coconut crops.

text.p: Rice and coconut crops have been badly hit by a devastating cyclone that swept through parts of the southeastern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, an agricultural expert said on Friday.

"Major crops that have been affected are coconut and rice," S.M. Virmani, an agricultural expert at the Hyderabad-based International Crop Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Crops, told Reuters by telephone.
"But it is too early to access the extent of damage," he said.
Police in Hyderabad said the death toll from the cyclone had climbed to 510.
Virmani said oilseed crops were not affected by the cyclone because harvesting of all the major oilseeds had been completed.
He said sea water had moved inland, affecting rice cultivation areas. "Therefore, productivity loss on these lands will be definitely there for the next five years," he said.
The cyclone crossed the coast 50 km (30 miles) south of Kakinada late on Wednesday. The storm has since weakened and moved deeper inland.

Earlier, one state official said nearly 250,000 hectares of rice paddy (625,000 acres) had been inundated and 450,000 hectares (1.12 million acres) of other crops, including chillies, banana plantations and coconut groves, were badly damaged.
The main force was felt in a low-lying coastal strip south of Kakinada port, an area with small farming communities in the fertile rice-growing region of the Godavari river delta.
